awd_abstract_narration: The University of Georgia through Dr. Charles Bender will               provide ten (10) students in chemistry an opportunity to                        understand computational chemistry and computer technology and                  will afford the undergraduate an opportunity to conduct a modest                research project using the knowledge they had gained from the                   workshops.  The students will investigate several scientific                    computer language, including symbolic types, such as LISP and it                will explore several kinds of computer architectures from the                   personal computers to high speed supercomputers.  The activity                  will be well supported by staff from computer vendors and will                  involve several Georgia staff who are authorities in Theoretical                Chemistry, pattern recognition, programming and protein                         sequencing.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
